HANDLING SILAGE L. W. CHASE Green com, such as is generally used for silage, is very heavy. The moisture content ranges from 60 to 85 per cent of the total weight of the corn. For this reason every means should be utilized to simplify the process of filling the silo and to reduce the labor and cost of handling the corn. Three general classes of equipment and methods of handling the corn are utilized to produce this result. They are: The large commercial outfit, the cooperatively owned large or small outfit, and the small indi - vidual outfit. Care should be exercised in selecting the size; for if too large a machine is purchased, it will require much more equipment to keep it running than if a smaller one is obtained. In the western part of the State where corn does not, as a rule, make more than four tons to the acre, a cutter which will cut eight tons per hour will have sufficient capacity for two corn binders, as each one of the latter machines will cut only about an acre an hour. Where the farmers own their own outfits and have only one or two silos to fill, the tendency seems to be toward purchasing smaller cutters and buying their own engines. EQUIPMENT AND HELP REQUIRED THE LARGE COMMERCIAL OUTFIT Where the large commercial outfit is hired and a cutter having a capacity of 18 or 20 tons is used, the following method m generally earned out: The corn is cut with two corn hinders; hauler! in with five or more teams, depending on the length of haul; four mtn arc used in the field to hand up the bundles; one man is used at the silo to help unload; one man to care for the cutter; and two or three are used in the silo to distribute and pack the silage. THE COOPERATIVELY OWNBO SMALLER OUTFIT It Is now a common practice for farmers to buy a 12- or 14 - int'h cutter cooperatively and use it on five or six Job* per season, Huch an outfit would have a capacity of 8 or 10 ton* per hour, and one com binder cutting steadily would be required to keep it at work; two men could do the loading In the field, while three teams would do the hauling. In most cases, the driver* would do the unloading.

4 E/tenaion HuUftin So. V>, College of Agriculture THE SMALL INDIVIDUALLY OWNED AND OPERATED OUTFIT Since tht pit itilo ha* come into u«e, there has been a demand for u small drau carrier outfit which can be operated with a four or five hone power hum engine, and which win cut 6 or 6 tonii of silage per hour. Two or three team* do the hauling, the driver* loading and unloading their own wagon*. The corn may be cut by a harvester in the morning and the filling otierations curried on in the afternoon: or a sled harvester may be uited. In the latter cane the hauling wagon in driven along»ide the harvester to make it convenient for the men who are doing the cutting to lay their armful* of corn on the wagon a* fart as they are gathered. Another method is to cut the com by hand and lay it upon the-Wagons as fast as cut. When only two or three men are available to operate one of these small outfits, a few acres of corn may be cut, then loaded and hauled, and cut into silage by the same men, only one of the processes being carried on at one time. CUTTING THE CORN Corn intended for silage is at the proper state of maturity when the kernels are denting and glazing. If it is cut before this stage is reached, part of the feeding value will be lost. Also, when cut too green, it makes a looser, more washy feed and contains more acid than if cut just at the proper time. If left until too ripe, the corn will make a drier feed and stock will not always clean it up. A fairly good grade of silage may be made by cutting corn after it is apparently dry, but plenty of water must then be applied as it is being put into the silo. Many farmers feel that they are repaid by cutting stover and making silage in this manner, especially in refilling silos which have been emptied one* after tilling in the fall. CORN CUTTERS Corn can be cut for silage with common corn knives, the sled harvester, or the corn binder. Corn knivti The use of corn knives is advisable only on very small jobs and then only when sled harvesters or corn binders are not available. When hand knives are used, the corn may be temporarily shocked, thrown onto the ground, or laid directly upon the wagons to be hauled to the silo. Sled harveiteri Tne sled harvester is probably the cheape»L of the three methods mentioned for cutting corn, but because it is such hard work for the men on the sled to catch the corn, the method is not popular. Bulletin 173, Office of Experiment Sta-

Handling Silugr 5 tions, United State Department of Agriculture, »Ut« that it cmi* $1,18 to cut corn with the tiled harvester, A short test at the University Farm Hhowed the cost wan $1,28 per acre for cut - ting and loading. Two men were able to harvest and load a ton every 10 minute* at a cost of about 17 cenU, but since they worked only about two-third» of the time, 40 ton* or about B iutik wan a good duy'ii work. Fig On» form of »M hirviwUr In using this machine moat efficiently, the wagon* used in hauling must be driven alongside the cutter and keep pace with it so the workmen can lay the corn directly on the wagons; other - wise the corn must be picked off the ground. It has been found that it costs about 10 cent* per ton to lift the bundles from the ground to the wagons, Corn binder* Altho it is fully as expensive and probably more so to cut corn for silage with a corn binder than by any other method, it no doubt is the most satisfactory, and the method to be most highly recommended. Since 7! acres per day is about the average amount cut with the corn binder, the farmer who is planning his work for filling his silo should estimate the tonnage per acre his corn will yield, and if he finds that one harvester will not keep the silage cutter supplied he should cut a day or so in advance, or have two or three com binders in the field at once. When the corn is cut by hand or with a sled it should seldom be laid on the ground, and if possible a bundle loading device should be used with the corn binders, as it has been found that it costs about $0.10 per ton to pick the corn from the ground and lay it on the wagons for loading.

6 Extension Bulletin No. b5, College of Agriculture The cost of cutting by hand and by sled harvester in the fore - going is baaed on results from United States Department of Agriculture, Bulletin No. 173. At the Nebraska Experiment Station the cost of cutting with the sled harvester and laying the com directly upon the wagons was found to be $1.98 per acre or $0,259 per ton. FIELD LOADING Field loading of either loose or bound com can best be accom - plished by allowing two men to hand up and one to arrange the bundles on the wagon. A careful test at the University Farm showed it to cost more per ton to use three men on the ground for each wagon than it aid to use two, but that it cost much less to load by having two men on the ground for each wagon than it did to have only one. In the first case the men are in each other's way or waiting for the man on the wagon, while in the second case the man on the wagon waits for the man on the ground. -4 Fig. 2 Method of loading hundlm onto rack w»gon» The bundle* should not be promiscuously thrown upon the wagon, as it has been found that by careful loading the total time spent in unloading may be reduced nearly 40 per cent. The loading should be planned in conjunction with the setting of the cutter. If the cutter can be set in a manner which will permit the teams to stand with their heads at the elevator end, the load - ing should commence at the rear of the wagon with the butts on the right of the rack, if the wagon stands at the right of the cutter; and vice vena, if the wagon stands on the opposite side of the cutter. If the hones must face the feeder end of the cutter, the load - ing should commence at the front end of the rack and the un - loading begin at the rear. If one man unloads the bundles they should all be laid on the rack in the order A, B,C, I), and E, figure 2, and the unloading take place in the opposite order E, D, C, B, and A. When two men unload, the ends of the rack are loaded first as explained under "Unloading (Jreen Com," page 7.

Handling Silage 7 HAULING IN CREEN CORN Figure 3 shows a convenient rack for hauling in green corn. The rack is made by hanging two bed pieces under the axle of the wagon and building a platform on these pieces. The frame is hung by a long kingbolt in front and stirrups over the bolster behind. When two or three teams are doing the hauling to a small cutter, one man will drive each team and'Joad his own wagon. When large capacity cutters are used and it is not possible to get the special silage racks, the flat topped racks and low wagons are found to be most convenient. Tests at the University Farm have shown that low wagons considerably lessen the cost of field loading. Fig. 3 A convenient rack for hauling ullage corn On 16 Nebraska farms, the average cost of hauling was found to be $3.37 per acre or $0,443 per ton for an average haul of 140 rods. The cost per ton of producing silage will depend consider - ably upon the distance the green com has to be hauled. It is important tha' the fields be u* close us possible to the silo. In one instance, it was found that it cost $0.39 more per ton to haul from a field a mile away than it did to haul from a field udjucent to the silo. In filling a 100-ton silo this would amount to $39. UNLOADING CREEN CORN One or two men may be used to unload the corn at the cutter. If two be used, one starts the unloading near the middle of the rack; and when an opening is made sufficiently large to allow room, a second man may assist. Figure 4 snows the wagon standing at the cutter. It also shows how the butu of the com on the front end of the load are turned opposite from thosi at the rear, when wagons are to be unloaded from the center toward the ends. This saves one man considerable time which would otherwise be spent in turning bundles to allow the butt ends to enter the cutter first. In short com where two tiers of bundles ran !>»• placed end to end across the rack, the butts are turned out.

Handling Silagf 9 Figure S show* a blower outfit fitted with a distributor. Thin dlntributor i» made In section* and In flexible, allowing *l\*uv to be blown to all part* of the nib. The blower pipe should be run m nearly vertical an powiible, otherwise more power will be consumed due to friction on the »iden of the tube. Hlower machine* are made in capacitie* ranging from 6 to 40 tons per hour. In moet inatancea the number of the machine expreeM* the width of throat or length of feed roll*. MACHINU UfINO CAHIIIBM The drag carrier operate* much like the old type of *truw carrier uaed on thre*hlng machines. It may be u*ed *uece*»fully In filling pit and aeml-pit »llo», but in not »uccei»fu) where a long carrier In required or in windy countries unleM the carrier In covered. The IncloNwl tulw given very little trouble, alnce it In light, compiu't, und ha» but one chuln.
